results.notes: When I turned over the leaves of these Maypples I expected to see the usual tiny orange flower-shaped aeciospores. Instead, I found the reddish brown asexual stage (teliospores). I’ve never seen this stage before, but have learned that this stage III of IV stages in the life cycle of rust is the resting stage which occurs in the summer and lasts over the winter until the following spring when the basidiospores are produced … and the cycle starts all over again. See the following link for other images and more information: http://www.extension.umaine.edu/... .

results.notes:
Growing a long a trail running through a hardwood forest. Red & white oaks, beech and ash in the immediate vicinity. Taste is mild, odor is very pleasant. Specimens in the hands of Nina & John Burghardt. Additional details could be posted later.
Collection description by J. & N. Burghardt:
“The closest we could get with Ray’s key is Russula sulcatipes. Caps were 4-5 cm, dull brown, flat (slightly uplifted near margin, sunken over the disk but with a prominent umbo which is reddish brown. Stipe is white, 30 mm by 10 mm widening to 15 mm at base, with fine longitudinal lines. Gills white to cream, narrow, close, with some forking near the stipe, a few long lamellulae. Spore deposit sparse, probably white to light cream. Spores are 7-9 × 6-7 microns, warts are small, a few lines to partial reticulum. It fit Ray’s description fairly well, except that Ray calls the gills “subdistant” and notes “conspicuous longitudinal ridges”. Also, he describes the stipe as “milky white”; however, ours had some discoloration by the time we looked at it in the evening."

results.notes:
The world of LichenS is made of coincidences, intuition and … sometimes blindness!
This observation has a funny story. It was at this place that I found one of my first Rinodina spp.. At the time I had doubts about its classification, but there were not many choices for a specimen with such features and the name Rinodina oleae soon came out. Thus, I planned this field trip to the place with the specific target focused on the Rinodina species known to exist there. Since it was observed on Juniperus shrubs, these made part of the target. It happens that the place of the observation has no other vegetation, except one fig tree and nothing else. Therefore, this day I went to the place and started to make my observations exactly at this fig tree and the first specimen seem was precisely the one in this observation. There, I thought that it could be a Lecanora; It was a clearly mature specimen, the apothecia were much wider than those I was looking for and the thallus was not as thin as I recall (see observation 215228 and compare). I spent more than two hours in the Juniperus shrubs around looking for what I had already encountered, without knowing. At the end I left the place somewhat frustrated in relation to the target, though I found there other beauties.

results.notes: Pileus 7-9 cm broad, plane to slightly uplifted at margin, dry, subtomentose to tomentose to matted subfibrillose, breaking up into areolate patches, lilac (13,14 D-E 4,3; grayish magenta). broadly short sulcate ridged at margin. Flesh white, unchanging, with farinaceous odor and taste. Lamellae adnexed to emarginate, crowded to close, whitish to yellowish white (4A2) with even margins, not staining. Stipe 4.5-6 cm long, 10-15 mm broad, equal, cylindrical, dry, lilac (as in pileus), white at base, heavily tomentose to fibrillose, rarely with some fine scales, with interior white, pithy, hollow in one. Spores globose to subglobose, amyloid, ornamented with short, conic spines or narrowly truncated warts. Clamp connections present. Pleurocystidia absent.

results.notes:
After all … this can be an undescribed species of Catillaria.

Let me first recall some facts from my observations of Catillaria. My first find was considered at observation 217407 and there I mentioned that the specimen had more than 8-spores per ascus, though I could not say how many. At the time I had doubts about the genus of that specimen. Recently I found again one specimen, treated in observation 238525, and conclude that it must belong to the genus Catillaria, but again I could not count the number of spores per ascus. There I recall the present understanding of that genus (though the Sonoran Flora Vol. III has almost 10 years, the British Flora from 2009 gave the same characterization) and I repeat it here:

“Catillaria in the broadest sense is characterized by lecideine to biatorine apothecia with small to moderate-sized, hyaline, 1-septate spores usually 8/ascus. It is still heterogeneous, and its relationships to other genera have not yet been fully clarified. Catillaria s. str. is characterized by asci with uniformly K/I+ blue apical dome, the abruptly swollen paraphysis tips with a dark brown cap, non-halonate ascospores, and the conidogenous cells in chains”.

As all the others, this specimen grew on wood of Juniperus shrubs. As in observation 238525, I include a photo illustrating the features of the genus in this specimen. This time I could get photos of the asci which clearly show that the number of spores is much bigger than 8. I cannot say for sure how many they are but certainly more than 20. In the set of photos labeled “Asci” the first photo shows an ascus where some spores are already out and one can count 14 spores inside. All the other asci in that photo set have more spores than the first one. The problem is that all the species considered in the Sonoran Flora have asci 8-spored and only one species with more than 8 spores per ascus is cited in the British Flora, namely C. gilbertii with 16 spores; however, this species is described as saxicolous.
Therefore, I have to look to other more recent references to see if there is anything similar to the specimens that I have been observed that may all belong to the same species.

At the end it was the more or less locally common one:Schismatoma graphidioides.

results.notes: Large truffle found amongst Abies grandis. The Peridium was an interwoven network of yellow and white hyphae. A nearly inch long stem attached it to the near mineral layer substrate. When severed, a gooey exudate briefly flowed from the stem. Upon cross sectioning, the Gleba revealed a cream colored, gooey columella. The rest of the gleba was composed of loosely packed hyphae. The truffle smelled like vanilla whey protein powder, or perhaps German chocolate cake. One might detect coconut notes.

results.notes:
Photo labeled “B” shows flatter fruit bodies with slightly darker undersides. I brought home material representing A, B, C. I’ll look at a few micro traits (soon) to confirm ID.

Spores from a deposit of collection B 17-20 × 8-9, and featuring both a coarse reticulatum of warts and apical projections. This coincides with the description of mature spores for A. aurantia as reported in AFNA. No spore drop from a fruit body from A, and a smash mount of material scraped from inside the cup showed a few spores that appeared to be smooth. This seemed to indicate two different species here. But AFNA says that the warts develop at maturity. So immature spores observed in smash mount are unlikely to show warts. Also, difference in maturity levels for the three fruitings seen here accounts for the slightly different appearances of the outer surfaces.

results.notes:
On intruded siliceous rock in a dry wash along Bitterwater Road in eastern San Luis Obispo County.

Thallus brown, areolate, with black immersed apothecia. The areoles are dispersed and do not show an effigurate shape and lacks prothallus. Still need to get chemistry done.
Spores muriform, hyaline becoming brown, large. Measurements: 43.4×12.6 41×19.6 34×12.2 35.9×13.

I had a heck of a time getting a good section of the apothecia, or well, actually I didn’t succeed in getting one because the areoles break off the rock as soon as you touch them with the blade. Instead I got kind of a mash of apothecia material so I don’t know how many ascospores per ascus. The large muriform spores don’t leave too many options, and rhizocarpon seems right in regards to spores, but the overall gestalt of this lichen doesn’t look like Rhizocarpon. I’ll get better photos and update this. Only three species known from this area, with Rhizocarpon bolanderi being the only one with spores of this size.

results.notes: This LBM has me a bit conflicted about the ID. Everything — EXCEPT the serrated gills — seems to fit Inocybe genus. The specimen was quite fresh so I’m unsure if the gills appear serrated due to being tattered by age. A solitary specimen fruiting in grass in suburban residential lawn. Cap: 3 cm., densely fibrillose, slimy/slippery with minutely serrated gills. Stem: 5 cm. X 6 mm., interesting white tufts at apex, hollow, stringy, bruises brownish when handled. KOH negative on cap. Brown spore print. Hopefully someone can help me sort this one out.

results.notes:
Lichenicolous fungus on Buellia.

This observation was created from observation 239974, since the presence of a lichenicolous fungus was noticed while observing under the microscope apothecia of the Buellia sp..
It is from the same place than observation 236813, where I found my first Minutoexcipula (or maybe it was Lichenodiplis). Most of the characters are the same – A producing conidia fungus parasitizing a lichen, by invading its apothecia – but this time the conidia is aseptate and the host is a Buellia sp. (B. erubescens), which is considered at observation 239974. Such conidial feature, together with the pycnidia like appearance of the ascomata, clearly points to the genus Lichnenodiplis. Consulting the website “Lichenicolous.net”:
http://www.lichenicolous.net/
one can see that there is a Lichenodiplis sp. having Buellia as host: L. fallaciosa. However, going to Ref. 2, its spores are bigger than those measured for this specimen. I contacted Javier Etayo who, based on the photographs, suggested the name L. pertusariicola for this specimen, taking into account that he knows about the occurence of that species growing over other Buellia sp.. My renewed acknowledgements to Javier Etayo for his help in the identifications of the lichenicolous I’ve been observed.

results.notes:
Non-fungal (host Ophrys insectifera)
Code: Bot_882/2015_DSC7023

Habitat: Steep, dray, stony mountain slope, sparsely overgrown, southeast aspect, colluvial, calcareous ground; exposed to direct rain, average precipitations ~ 3.000 mm/year, average temperature 7-9 deg C, elevation 545 m (1.800 feet), alpine phytogeographical region.

Substratum: soil among stones.

Place: Lower Trenta valley between villages Soča and Trenta, above the main road Bovec – Vršič near Matevž farm house, Trenta 1, East Julian Alps, Posočje, Slovenia EC.

Comments: When I observed this orchid (Ophrys insectifera) I thought that I found a new location of this quite rare species in Trenta valley. Only after I started to photograph it with my macro-lens I observed something closely resembling tiny sporocarps of a fungus on plant’s stem. Excited I thought I found an interesting ascomycete on an unusual host. Only later under the microscope I realized that this could not be so. To my knowledge structures observed could not be explained as something pertaining to fungi world. Having no clue what it might be I sent the photos to Mgr. Gabriel Seljak at Agriculture and Forestry Institute, Nova Gorica. He kindly explained me that such structures are most probably build by certain insects, either plant eating bugs of suborder Heteroptera or insects of the family Cicadidae. They put their eggs into a wound made by a sharp special organ. Which species is especially interested in orchids is an interesting question? No definite answer can be given based on these photos.

Anyway, although very interesting looking for an amateur mycologist at the beginning, the small ‘craters’ are non-fungal.

Nikon D700/Nikkor Micro 105mm/f2.8

results.notes:
Growing on a piece of rock in a calcareous habitat, close to the sea border.
My impression on the field was that this could be a weird Diplotomma; Nevertheless, I collected a sample that just analyzed. Starting with a section of an apothecium immediatly realized to be in presence of something completely different than thought. Going further the KOH reaction on the section was negative, simply enhanced the yellowish coloration of a part of the hymenium. Further, pressing the slide could see paraphyses with dark tips but not much enlarged and small asci, clavate and somewhat flexuosus, containing 8 hyaline 1-septate spores inside. The asci apex showed a big tholus and a prominent apical beak, like that in Bacidia-type asci. This was unexpected and the first task was to establish the genus of this specimen. Using Ref. 2 the answer was Lecania!
My knowledge of this genus is very limited and I only identified before one of its species, but not based on microscopic properties. After noting the spores form – ellipsoid to fusiform many of them with a cell bigger than the other, sometimes but not always fusiform – and their dimensions:
(10.7) 11.3 – 12.9 (14.1) × (3.7) 4.3 – 5 (5.3) µm
Q = (2.3) 2.4 – 2.9 (3) ; N = 22
Me = 12.1 × 4.6 µm ; Qe = 2.6
went to the keys. Before it is worth mention that many small crystals were found in the slides, that to a certain extent caused several difficulties in the observation of asci and spores.
In the Sonoran Flora Vol. 2, I was lead to a group of species formed by L. chalcophila, L. rayiana and L turicensis. The same exercise in the British Flora leads to L turicensis, if considering white pruinose thallus or apothecia, or L. sylvestris, in the other case and taking into account the calcareous substrata. In my opinion the opinion the thallus and the apothecia are epruinose or only slightly pruinose.
It should be mentioned that L. chalcophila and L. rayiana are not mentioned in the British Flora and that L. sylvestris is not mentioned in the Sonoran Flora.
The next step was the IKI staining of the asci, which gave another surprise; I think that the asci are of the “Biatora-type”, characterized by an ascus tholus that has a more or less conical ocular chamber and a high conical axial body surrounded by an amyloid zone darker than the rest of the stained apex. If this is so, than most of the above cited species are ruled out (by having “Bacidia-type asci”, according to the Sonoran Flora) with the exception of L. sylvestris, according to Ref. 3. Maybe this point has to be clarified.
Finally, let me mention that, according to Ref. 3, L. sylvestris has a thin and granular, sometimes immersed, thallus and that the spores have 11.1–11.4 × 2.9–3.4 mm, being ellipsoid to fusiform, but the sketch illustrating they form only shows fusiform ones. In my specimen most probably the thallus, which is not immersed, should be classified as areolate and the range for the spores dimensions are bigger than that.

results.notes:
TZ #100 Tanzanian Amanita
Collection date: Jan 29, 2016
Collection ID: TZ #100
Collected by: Johannes (Johann) Harnisch
www.mushroomobserver.com posted on this site as Observation # 240597 http://mushroomobserver.org/240597?q=2mo6a
Collection location: Mufindi, Mafinga, Iringa, Tanzania, East Africa. On red unfertile earth, In Miombo woodlands (images of surrounding trees/plants also collected). Solitary or in groups of 5 or more.
GPS Location: 36M 730,260.2e 9,068,627.7n (UTM format) 6,275 feet elevation
Collected in the rainy season, rained night before collection.
3 specimens collected for description.
Pileus: Color white, darkening to cinnamon brown with maturity, center darker brown than margin. Shape convex expanding to slightly depressed in center and margin raising upward yet still curved downward at extreme margin. Striate 1/10 ratio, surface slightly tacky, with fibrils, and patches at center.
Universal Veil on pileus: cinnamon brown, leaving patches at center and fibrils up to the margin, adhering but easily scraped off.
Lamellae: white then dull white and brown with age, adnate to free, breadth 12mm.
Stipe: Flesh turning light brown when cut. Length 60-120mm, width 10-13mm, Color: White background with brown fibrils, flesh bruising brown otherwise white. Hollow with age, stuffed while immature. Widening toward base-up to 16mm wide at extreme base. Dry.
Veil evanescent of absent.
Volval sac present, dull white, becoming brown.
Odor faint and earthy.

This observation is part of the study of Amanita in Tanzania, and includes the images of the specimens and the nearby vegetation.
The dried specimens and descriptions will be sent to Rod for examination.

Medium sized Amanita. One soft textured, very fragile, single, solitary, specimen collected and described.
Pileus: 105mm diameter, 13mm thick, white, convex, not striate, context thick, suddenly thinning at margin. Soft. Dry.
Lamellae: Ivory white, touching stipe i.e. not free, adnate, nearly distant. Lamellulae present between each full lamellae and extending 25% of the distance from pileus margin to stipe apex.
Stipe: Length- apex to top of bulb- 70mm, mid-span width 25mm. Gradual enlarging toward base, solid, with small cotton like patches. White, fragile.

Bulb: 50mm long, then suddenly tapering, tapered portion tap root like and projecting at least 25mm beyond bulb base. Rooting. Bulbous base width max 32mm, white with small dirty brown specs, no staining,
Universal veil remains on pileus, cream, white, slightly yellowish. Soft cotton like patches easily pealed off surface.
Odor strong, nearly of mothballs or cleaner.

This observation is part of the study of Amanita in Tanzania, and includes the images of the specimens and the nearby vegetation.

White medium sized Amanita, commonly found under eucalyptus in groups, clusters, or fairy rings in grass under eucalyptus. Exclusively under eucalyptus.
One mature specimen and three eggs used here for description.

Pileus: convex expanding, flattening, surface smooth or cracking slightly tacky.
White or ivory, no staining, Diameter 70mm, 6mm deep at stipe apex.

Stipe: length (apex to rim of volva) 55mm, 15mm mid span diameter, tapering upward, interior hollow, flesh white, smooth.
Veil remnants on stipe, white, thin membranous.
Volval sac: dry, white, leaving an 8-30mm rim around enlarged stipe base.
Base: 32-35mm diameter, slightly tapering downward.
Lamellae: dull white, nearly yellow or Ivory. Moderately close. Free, Margins minutely ragged. Lamellulae present, 7mm deep.
Odor: slight, musty or unpleasant.

This observation is part of the study of Amanita in Tanzania, and includes the images of the specimens and the nearby vegetation.
The dried specimens and descriptions will be sent to Rod for examination.

results.notes:
First observed 5/15/16, growing on a rotting Betula lenta stick. Cap diameter at maturity (today) 65-90 mm in greatest dimension. Cap relatively smooth but radially lined with darker fibers. Stipes short and tapering, eccentric, black at the point of attachment,11-13 mm thick at base. Pores angular, 3-4/mm, bruising brown, greatly stretched at some places but not eroded. Tubes appear to be stratified up to 4 layers at some places, single thickness in others, greatest depth 4 mm. Flesh tough, thickness away from the stipe up to 7 mm. Smell pleasantly spicy. Taste not distinctive. KOH on flesh briefly concolorous with cap color, then reverts to cream.

A typical fresh specimen of Cerioporus leptocephalus found today has an unstreaked cap surface, but smells, bruises, and responds identically to KOH. If the observation species is also C. leptocephalus, it’s a ridiculously robust mutant.
